steps.title: The moon cycles through 8 phases about once every 29.5 days.
steps.content: The moon cycles through 8 phases about once every 29.5 days. The moon doesnâ€™t shine light of its own, but reflects light from the sun. As the moon orbits Earth and Earth orbits the sun, we donâ€™t get a continuous view of the side of the moon thatâ€™s facing the sun (and therefore lit up). Most of the time, our view of the moon shows part of the sunlit side and part of the dark side at the same time. How much of the sunlit side we can see determines which phase of the lunar cycle weâ€™re in: [6] X Research source New moon: The moon appears completely dark or black because the sun is illuminating the other side. Waxing crescent: We begin to see sunlight along the moonâ€™s right edge as more of its surface is lit from our point of view. First quarter: The moon appears half full (itâ€™s lit on the right side and dark on the left). Waxing gibbous: The moon appears more than half full as it approaches becoming a full moon. Full moon: The entire side of the moon facing Earth is lit. Waning gibbous: The right edge of the moon becomes dark as less of the moon is sunlit from our point of view. Third quarter: The moon appears half full (itâ€™s lit on the left side and dark on the right, the opposite of the first quarter moon). Waning crescent: A sliver of sunlight can be seen along the moonâ€™s left edge (the opposite of the waxing crescent moon). Did you know? The moon rotates on its axis at the same speed it orbits Earth due to the gravitational interactions between the two bodies. This means that from Earth, we always see the same side of the moon (or as they say scientifically, the moon and Earth are tidally locked ).
